LEO Station Keeping
Prev Samples and Tutorials Next

LEO Station Keeping

Objective and Overview

In this tutorial, you will learn how to use the GMAT's control flow and targeting mechanisms to maintain a Low-Earth orbit in the presense of atmosphere drag. For the sake of simulation time, we will make the area-to-mass ratio of the spacecraft large, to make the drag cause a rapid lowering of the orbit semimajor axis. The process used in this script is also useful for generating delta-V estimates for LEO stationkeeping of real-world missions. The basic steps of this tutorial are:

  1. Create and configure the Resourse Tree - configure a spacecraft, impulsive maneuver, propagator, XY plot, and differential corrector.

  2. Create a conditional loop using a While statement , to propagate the mission for 10 days.

  3. Run the mission (we will call it mission's Part 1)and observe its behavior when using no orbit control strategy.

  4. Add Part 2 - a control target sequence nested in an If statement that executes at altitudes below 342 km (where drag is a serious factor) and keep the altitude above 342 km.

  5. Run the Part 2 mission; observe the behavior of the orbit altitude with the control strategy implemented in step 4.

Creating and Configuring the Resource Tree

Here we will configure a model of a LEO spacecraft, a propopagator, a maneuver, and an XY plot that we will use to visualize the semi-major axis (SMA) during the control sequence that we will develop in the next section.

Creating the Spacecraft

  1. In the Resource Tree, right-click DefaultSC, select Rename, change the name to LEOsat.

  2. Open the LEOsat dialog box/window (for that, right-click --> Open or double left-click on LEOsat) . Set the value in the EpochFormat combo box to UTCGregorian.

  3. Set the Epoch to 05 Jan 2010 00:00:00.000

  4. Set the state elements to these values: X = -4083.9 , Y = 4691.8 , Z = -2576.7 , VX = -4.252 , VY = -5.509 , VZ = -3.284

  5. Your LEOsat window should now look like as shown below. If not, make changes as needed. Click OK to save and close.

Figure: LEOsat Spacecraft Object

Creating the Propagator

  1. Right-click DefaultProp. Select Rename, and change the name to LEOprop.

  2. Open LEOprop dialog box.

  3. In Drag model group box, set the Atmosphere Model to JacchiaRoberts.

  4. Click Select button to the right of the Point Masses list. Add the Sun and Luna as Point Masses to the right-hand side list. Click OK.

  5. Check the box Use Solar Radiation Pressure

  6. Now your LEOprop dialog window should look like the screen capture below. Click OK to save.

Figure: LEOprop Propagator Object

Creating the DifferentialCorrector and Maneuver

We will use the default configurations for the maneuver and the differential corrector . Follow these steps:

  1. In the Resource Tree, locate the Solvers folder; expand it if necessary.

  2. Right-click the Boundary Value Solvers, then Add and select DifferentialCorrector.

  3. Rename the added corrector as DC.

  4. In the Burns folder, right-click on DefaultIB, rename it as DeltaV.

  5. Specify the output: right-click the Output folder, click Add, then XYPlot. Open XYPlot box; click Edit X; replace the item in the right-hand column with A1ModJulian; click OK. Click Edit Y; replace the item in the right-hand column with Altitude; click OK. Your XYPlot box sdhould now look as shown below. Click OK to save it..

    Figure: XYPlot Object

Configuring the Mission Sequence

We will implement the mission in two parts. In Part 1 we will set a While loop with a propagate sequence, and will configure it to propagate for about 10 days. This will still lack any orbit control strategy - upon running the mission you will see the SMA drop below the allowed value of 342 km. Later in Part 2 a control sequence will be added, to ensure that SMA remains above approximately 342 km. Below is an illustration of the Mission Tree after you have completed Part 1. Follow the steps below.

  1. In the Mission Tree, right-click Propagate1, select Insert After, select Control Logic, select While.

  2. Right-click While1, select Insert After, select Propagate (it will appear as Propagate2). Your Mission Tree should now look as shown below.

    Figure: Mission Tree, Part I

Now we will configure the While1 sequence so that the ElapsedDays of LEOsat are limited to 10 days, and configure the Propagate2 command to take a single propagation step.

  1. Open the Propagate1 command dialog box.

  2. In the Stopping Conditions group, double-left click the Parameter field to select the text LEOSat.ElapsedSecs. Delete this text (using the Delete or Backspace key).

  3. In the Stopping Conditions, double-left click the Condition field to select the text 12000. Delete it.

  4. Your Propagate1 box should now look like the screen below. Click OK to save and close it.

    Figure: Propagate1 Command

  5. Open the While1 dialog box.

  6. Note that the value in the Left-Hand Side column is already set to LEOSat.ElapsedDays, and the conditional operator is set to "<" (less-than). We will leave those fields at this default.

  7. Change the Right-Hand Side value to10.0.

  8. Your While1 dialog box should look like the screen below. Click OK to save and close it.

    Figure: While1 Command

We are now ready to run the first part of the mission and observe the evolution of the LEOsat altitude. Click Run in the Toolbar. A plot should appear looking similar to the illustration below. Notice that the alttitude drops below the allowed value of 342 km. We will address this issue below, in the mission's Part 2, by implementing a relevant control strategy.

Figure: Output Mission Part 1

Just in case you may want in the future to return to the mission executed in Part 1, this is a good point to save your mission under an appropriate name. In order to avoid confusion, you may want to also save it under the nmae that reflects its becoming the Part 2 mission.

In Part 2, every time the orbit dips below 342 km, the control strategy that we will set up will perform a Hohmann transfer, increasing the orbit altitude. (We assume that by now you know how to configure a Hohmann transfer in GMAT. (If you want to refresh your knowledge, use the Hohmann Transfer Tutorial.)

In the Mission Tree, let us add the Part 2 mission sequence

  1. Add an If statement after the Propagate2 Command.

  2. Add a Target statement inside the If statement

  3. Add a Vary statement inside Target1.

  4. Add a Maneuver after Vary1.

  5. Add an Achieve command after Maneuver1

  6. Add a Propagate command after Achieve1

  7. Add a Vary Command after Propagate3

  8. Add a Maneuver after Vary2

  9. Add an Achieve after Maneuver2

The figure below illustrates how your Mission Tree should now look like. .

Figure: Mission Tree, Part II

Let us now configure the commands created above, to perform the Hohman transfer control sequence.

  1. Open the If1 command dialog box

  2. Set the Left Hand Side value to LEOsat.Altitude

  3. Set the Right Hand Side value to 342. Click OK to save and close the box.

    Figure: If1 Command

  4. Open the Vary1 Command dialog box .

  5. Change the IntialValue field to 0.002. Click OK to save.

    Figure: Vary1 Command

  6. Open the Achieve1 Command dialog box.

  7. Edit the Goal value to LEOsat.Earth.SMA.

  8. Change the Value to 6734. Click OK to close.

    Figure: Achieve1 Command

  9. Open the Propagate3 command dialog box.

  10. In the Stopping Conditions group, change the Parameter field to LEOSat.Earth.Apoapsis.

  11. In the Stopping Conditions group, delete data in the Condition field. Your box should now look as shown below. Click OK to save it.

    Figure: Propagate3 Command

  12. Open the the Vary2 command dialog box.

  13. Set Initial Value= 0.001; Perturbation=0.00005; Lower=-9.999999e300; Upper=9.999999e300; Max Step=0.001. Your box should look as shown below. Click OK to save.

    Figure: Vary2 Command

  14. Open the Achieve2 Command dialog box.

  15. Edit the Goal value to LEOsat.Earth.ECC.

  16. Set Value=0.0005; Tolerance=0.0001. Your dialog box should now look as shown below. Click OK to close.

    Figure: Achieve2 Command

Running the Mission

We are now ready to run our Part 2 mission. Press Run. An XY plot showing the behavior of the spacecraft altitude should appear; in its final form it should look similar to the illustration below. Notice that, with the altitude control sequence now added, the spacecraft initiates an altitude-boosting maneuver every time its altitude dips below the allowed 342 km. You may want to save this script now, in case you decide to return to it in the future.

Figure: Output Mission Part 2
